description: From French exprès, from Latin expressus, past participle of exprimere (see Etymology 2, below).

adjectives.description: express (comparative more express, superlative most express)

entries.meaning: (not comparable) Moving or operating quickly, as a train not making local stops.
(comparable) Specific or precise; directly and distinctly stated; not merely implied.
examples: Synonyms: explicit, plain; see also Thesaurus:explicit
I gave him express instructions not to begin until I arrived, but he ignored me.
This book cannot be copied without the express permission of the publisher.
In my eyes it bore a livelier image of the spirit, it seemed more express and single, than the imperfect and divided countenance.

entries.meaning: (postpositive, retail) Providing a more limited but presumably faster service than a full or complete dealer of the same kind or type.
Moving or operating quickly, as a train not making local stops.
examples: The train runs express to 96 St.

entries.meaning: A mode of transportation, often a train, that travels quickly or directly.
examples: I took the express into town.

entries.meaning: A service that allows mail or money to be sent rapidly from one destination to another.

examples: "Give me my express," I said, laying down the Winchester, and he handed it to me cocked.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A clear image or representation; an expression; a plain declaration.
A messenger sent on a special errand; a courier.
examples: I learned, to my inexpressible terror, that at two o'clock, the day before, an express had been sent to Geraldine by Mr Bergasse, with a letter, which he had received from the Hotel de Romagnecourt.
She charged him  […]  to ask at the express if anything came up from town.

entries.meaning: That which is sent by an express messenger or message.

description: From Old French espresser, expresser, from frequentative form of Latin exprimere.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) The action of conveying some idea using words or actions; communication, expression.
examples: Whereby they discoursed in silence, and were intuitively understood from the theory of their expresses.
This Gentleman [...] caused a man to go down no less than a hundred fathom, with express to take notice whether it were hard or soft in the place where it groweth.

verbs.description: express (third-person singular simple present expresses, present participle expressing, simple past and past participle expressed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To convey or communicate; to make known or explicit.
examples: Words cannot express the love I feel for him.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To press, squeeze out (especially said of milk).
examples: It contained many cysts which were filled with sagolike granules that could be expressed under pressure.

entries.meaning: (biochemistry) To translate messenger RNA into protein.
(biochemistry) To transcribe deoxyribonucleic acid into messenger RNA.
examples: When a cell “expresses” a gene, it translates the DNA first into a signature messenger RNA (mRNA) sequence and subsequently into a chain of amino acids that forms a protein.
